File:Hand-drawn bells with ribbon
In the "little town of Bethlehem"
One "silent holy night"
"Away in the manger" a babe was born
Who was born to be "the light"
And "shepherds watched their flocks by night"
As the angels sang on high
For God had given us His gift of love
"O come all ye Faithful" and let us draw nigh
C.J.H
WISHING YOU A JOYOUS CHRISTMAS AND A BLESSED NEW YEAR 
THE HARDER FAMILY
Completed

2-14-71
printed address label  David B. Hargett  111-C 16th Place, S.W.   Birmingham, Ala.  35211
Dear Jack,

   Sorry it's been so long since I last wrote, but my job keeps me busy.  I'm now managing the draperies, bedspreads, lamps and china department of Sears Roebuck in Bessemer Ala.  Here I'll stay (probably 1 or 2 years) until I prove myself good enough to get kicked up the executive ladder.  So far there's plenty of hard work but no ulcer, even if I did run the toy department during Christmas.
   My social life is OK, I read a lot, buy a lot of records, and generally get along O.K.  so I have no complaints.  Except that Uncle Sam is breathing down my neck.  He'd rather I be shooting Viet Cong than paying my $1200.00 in taxes like I did for 1970.  Misplaced values, don't you think?
     How are things with you and your wife?  How's the book coming along?  Drop me a line and let me know how things are going.

David
Completed

letterhead  David B. Hargett    2152 Prentiss Dr., Apt. 302     Downers Grove, Illinois  60515
May 17, 1975
Dear Jack -

   Congratulations!  I just read about your honorayr doctorate from Missouri in today's underlined:  Daily News.  (Clipping enclosed).  I'm glad to see you get some overdue recognition.
   I'm still with Sears in Chicago, recently promoted to Assistant Retail Sales Manager of the Children's Department in charge of our Eastern Territory which includes the Middle Atlantic and New England states.  My career is still forging ahead.
   As for my personal life, I'm getting married on September 20th to a lovely young lady from Rockford, Illinois.
    Congratulations again on your academic honors.  I hope you and your wife are doing well.

Sincerely,
Dave Hargett
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Hargett, David B.  [no date]

    I'm enclosing a story of mine that I don't think you've ever seen.  I wrote it two years ago and have since collected two rejection slips.  Any comments or suggestions on markets I might try would certainly be appreciated.
    Keep plugging away at that autobiography -- and remember, I want one of the first copies (autographed of course!)!

Cordially, 
David B. Hargett

All is well and hope when these few line reach your loveing [sic] kind hands it will find you & Husband very well.  Glady I have been thanking [sic] of you.  So I thought I write I have ben [sic] the house with the flue. for a week that why I didn't Call you up.  I have a mother  [sic] week to stay in I'm tired of this house.  (Smill). [sic]

Hedgerloy
Haste Hill.
Boughton Monchelsea
Maidstone Kent
May  19th 1964
Dear Frank,

      Thank you for your letter.  I am sorry to have been rather long in replying but was not quite certain when I should be going on holiday.  However that has now been fixed for July 24th-Aug 1st.  My step-daughter and family come here for the second week in Aug.  If your friends could arrange their visit to Maidstone and district any time after the 15th Aug. we should be pleased to give them a welcome.  Dick hopes to be available to take them around the Chatham area.  Please, no further present from you.  I had that last year.
     I was glad to hear you and Mabel are both fairly well, and hope she is feeling more able to cope with things in general.  My family and I have kept very well.  The grand-children seem to be growing up very fast.  The village school children celebrated May Day this year and last week I sent Mabel a paper with a photgraph [sic] taken on the green which I thought might interest her as it shows the
Completed

the cottages opposite the old forge.

   We had lovely sunny warm weather here last week, the best up to now of the year.  The countryside has looked very lovely with the pear and apple blossom and all the different shades of green in the trees.
    Hoping I shall have the pleasure of meeting your friends and with best wishes from yours sincerely

Ethel Harris

Hedgerley
Haste Hill
Boughton Monchelsea
Maidstone, Kent
Jan 18th 1965
Dear Mr & Mrs Conroy.

     Thank you for your card and good wishes, received at Christmas.  My son called in on his way home from work the day of your vital-? thinking there was just the chance you might still be here.  He too was sorry to have missed you and that you were unable to visit the ? places of interest which he had arranged with a friend to show you.  However as you say, you hope to make another trip at some future date, perhaps there will be more time then.
   I have heard from Frank & Mabel Mead quite recently, they seem to be going ahead with their plans to come to Ireland to live.  So hope things will
Completed

run smoothly for them.

   Up to now we haven't had any severe cold weather, but plenty of rain and strong gales of wind.  However the days are just a little longer the birds getting active and the bulbs showing through in the garden, which is a sign spring is ahead.
  Carolyn would be very pleased I know, if you could send her one of your books.  She's so very fond of reading.  Last week she was home from school with a bad cold, which didn't suit her one little bit.
   I hope you and your family are well.  With kind wishes from  

Yours sincerely
Ethel Harris
Completed

Elm Villa
Green Lane,
Boughton Monchelsea
Maidstone
Kent
19th May, 1967
Dear Jack Conroy,

     Thank you very much for your copy of your latest book.  It is very kind of you to remember me after what was, after all, a very small service which I performed.  If you are ever over here again please do not hesitate to get in touch with me.  similarly, if any of your friends would like to meet a real genuine native
Completed

(2)
your are quite at liberty to give them my address.

     I am writing this in haste, as I have just realised that I have destroyed the book wrapper which gave your full address.   I shall give this letter to Mabel Mead who leaves for the States next week, and hope that Frank will be able to send it on to you.
    I have not had time to read more than the first three chapters of your book but find it very interesting.  I expect you will understand that
Completed

3
American history is a closed book to most of us over here.

   I must say this book is very different from your children's book.  You must be a very versatile personality!
   I am glad to say that my mother and family are all very well.  My daughter Carolyn continues to show promise at school.  She has now left the local village school and goes into Maidstone.
   I hope this small letter will reach you in due course.

With best wishes
Yours sincerely
Dick Harris
Completed

note in upper left corner of page  Jack:  Harris works for an insurance company at Tunbridge Wells.  Used to be at Chatham.  F.M.
Elm Villa
Green Lane,
Boughton Monchelsea
Maidstone
Kent
1st December, 1973
Dear Frank, 

     My mother has passed on to me the copy of your Chicago Daily News Panorama with its article on Jack Conroy.  I never realised when he was here that he was important enough to merit an article in such a large paper.
      I could recognise him in the photo at the Sugar Creek graveyard, but not the one in his study.  We still have his book "The Disinherited, and I had always thought that it was largely auto-biographical.
      I expect that in the U.S.A. you are beginning to worry about the effects of the oil shortage, as we are here.  Coupons are now being issued for the petrol rationing which will probably start before Christmas.  As I believe you know I work in Tunbridge Wells, and I don't suppose I shall get sufficient petrol
Completed

to make the daily  journey by car.  By bus into Maidstone and then train to Tunbridge Wells will probably take 1 ½ hours, compared with 35 minutes by car.

     The coal-miners have taken the opportunity to "work to rule" in an effort to get higher wages, and also some of the electrical power workers, so that the immediate future looks pretty bleak.
    However, it is no good looking on the gloomy side.  I expect we shall have a merry Christmas and wish you one too.
    Mother is quite well.  She has fully recovered from her broken ankle, although I don't think she walks quite as far as she used to.
    With best wishes from us in Kent.

Yours sincerely
Dick Harris

December 26, 1946
Dear Jack,

    Many thanks for your Christmas card.  It was forwarded to me.
    We see where you and Bontemps have done another book -- the one about the little man who painted the very realistic signs.  Congratulations.  I hope it has the best success imaginable.
    I'm doing a book now on Vachel Lindsay -- a novel in which he is the central character.  In several weeks I hope to have part of it, at least, ready for submission to publishers.   Pellegrini & Cudahy in Chicago offers a $2,100 Fellowship.  Do you know anything about them?  It's a new publishing house.
    I had hoped to meet your side-kick Bontemps down at Fisk.  But after leaving St. Louis I went to Springfield, Illinois, to live with my wife and to do Lindsay research.  I was unfortunate enough to catch pneumonia.  Thus Albuquerque.  And I had to forego the Fisk trip as too strenuous in my weakened condition.
    Do you ever get down this way?  If so, we would certainly enjoy being your hosts.  We'll point out the mountains to you.  Jo, my wife, is thinking of doing a children's book with an Indian theme.  At the moment, however, she is somewhat too busy supporting me to dig in.   There is an Indian and Spanish flavor to this place as you no doubt know.
   Horace Cayton visited me when he was in Springfield recently.   He seemed like a very nice guy and we liked him.  If you see him, please tell him so.  Also have had some correspondence with John Scoon, Holt's representative in Chicago.  Do you know him?
   That seems to wind it up for now.  Again, many thanks for your card.  Please have a happy new year of all good things.

Best regards handwritten:  Mark
Mark Harris
510 East Silver
Albuquerque, New Mexico
PS - used "They Seek A City" for research on the Springfield, (Ill.) race riot of 1908, and thanks --
Completed

February 24, 1951
Dear Sir Jack,

    SAM PATCH arrive here today, and we thank you very much.  He will be Hester Jill's first friend in fiction when the time comes.  Meanwhile Jo and I will read the book and make sure there are no swear words or subtle un-Americanisms.
    Please do not be offended because I am paying for it with the enclosed rubber check.  It is a matter of principle with us to do so with regard to books which are things so many people seem to think come out of thin air at no expense to anybody.
    I believe all the news of importance from here is contained in my letter of the other day.  Again, many thanks for the book, and when you have time be sure to let us hear from you.

mh
3102 south logan street
englewood  colorado
P.S.  We (Joe I) just read the book & enjoyed it.  Also liked the illustrations.  We know that Hester Jill will like it & ask for it to be read to her many times.  
mh
Completed

July 25, 1952
Dear Jack,

   Here's another letter for the pile on the diningroom table.
   I have returned BEHOLD, THY BROTHER to you under separate cover.   I read it while waiting for the bus and thought it an earnest little job.
   With this letter I send you a letter I received today.  I will write to them and accept their invitation.  If for any reason you think I ought [[underlined:  not] to accept it, please say so.  It sounds as if it might be helpful to me.  Please return the letter and tell me what you think.
   I was happy to find, upon returning here, that Hester Jill has nothing more serious than measles.  She was home from the hospital when I got here, much to my relief.
   I much enjoyed my brief Chicago visit, and I much thank you and Gladys for your hospitality.  Best regards to you both.  If you approve, I will see you February 26.

mh
517 16th Ave SE
Minneapolis, Minnesota
[[added in handwriting]  There is also a Chicago outfit called Friends of American Writers, which gives $1000 a year to the author of the best book on the midwest.  If you have any influence with them make them give me that 1,000 for 1952.  Also, (over)
Completed
do you suppose these Friends of Literature will pay my transportation at least?

As ever,

red ink at bottom of page  underlined:  New Republic Harris
Completed

Dear Jack

   Thought you might like to see that your review of Menken's letters ran in the local aftenblatt and where it ran.  Ultra Room is the local version of the pre Castro peep shows in Havana.  Except here you sit alone and look through one way glass at two little broads blowing each other off along with a bit of flogging and other Sado/Maso crap.
   Which reminds me...
          It was said of the Marquis de Sade
          And he must have found it rather odd
          That the Baron von Masoch
          Put him over a hassock
          And reversed their positions by God.
   This year we didn't have our usual January in Baja.  At about 03:00 hours on December 17, I was struck by a stroke.  I lay in the dark, felt my left side go numb and cold.  Later saw my  mouth sag and dribble. 
   It scarde [sic] Hell out of me, gave me religion.. Now I am a confirmed Ecopalian.  That's an Episcopalian with the piss scared out of him.
   But then, things got better fast.  So much so that we spent a week in Santa Barbara between my second brain scan and a consultation with my  internist.
   I should have held out for Baja.  Even comparing pre-devaluation prices and accomodations, Santa Barbara isn't in it with Mexico.  At that, it was not too bad.
   What burned me most was not driving my shiny new Alfa Romeo the shole [sic] route.  Leave it to my luck to splurge seven grand on a new car and then get hit with yet another 'stroke' of bad luck.
    Ah well, at least we're not asshole deep in snow.  I read of 144 inches in Buffalo...that's 12 feet of God Damned snow.  Why can't we ship some of that out to the Sierras to relieve our drought?
    Who knows?  Any day now there will be a movement of tectonic plates.  The Pacific plate will move away from the North American plate and the whole damn West coast will sink into the Pacific.
    Since the whole fault line zags way East of LA, San Diego and Baja perhaps, by then, I'll have retired to la Mision and can shrug off the whole cataclysim. [sic]
    Meanwhile, keep in touch.  Whatever happens, we have little time to keep on exchanging letters.

Keep the faith...if you can ever find out what it is.
George
PS Give Gladys two hugs - one from Alice, one from me.
Completed

Some of his comments about politics are great, like telling of the man who went down to Parliment [sic] for 30 years and never opened his kisser.  A wonderful description.
Then commenting on how one of the gentrywith [sic] whom he served on a school board had given him permission to Roam over his Beautiful Grounds and shoot.  Hawker said, "But when you give a poacher permission to kill game you take the Sugar out of the ginger bread.  You rob him of the pleasure it is to an expert poacher to steal a march not only on the game but on the men who claim it for their own.  I have poached more for Revenge than for Gain.  Because the Class poached upon my liberty when I was not able to defend myself."
Well oldfriend, I've more letters to write.  Laid up with a cold and so unable to get to Big Sur and plan to write no less than 30 letters.
Hope I'll get a few back.
George
P.S.  ? to ?, this Hawker was the"illiterate" son of a tailor - hence the quaint punctuation and capitalization
Completed

Dear Jack

   I know you'll be fascinated by "Flaky Paint Around Windows",  "The Swing to Steel Sinks," and especially by God's plan for congenital imbecility and deformity.
  Because of a congenital deformity in my right eye, I have had to wear glasses for as long as I can remember.  Remembering how my soul was nourished by school boy taunts of "Four eyes" and "Barney Google With The Googly Gogly Eyes"  I really envy those monsters who are privileged to serve God's highest purposes.
   In case you hadn't heard, God is not dead....he's living in the White House.
   Here in San Francisco, we are with Shriners.  We're up to our ass(s) in Shriners.   80,000 (maybe 100,000) of them.
   And we are with Shriner Jokes...Can't remember your name but the fez is familiar familiaa...The Shrine Cocktail, gin fez served in a Mason jar.
Completed

Can you have pity for a cop?  I can.  Special, Captain Zagarosa, head of our traffic detail.  Come tomorrow, the Fourth, he'll have to cope with a several hour long Shrine parade, a threatened invasion by Hell's Angels, a ball game at Candlelstick [sic] Park and a regatta and fireworks  (pyrotechnic) display off Marina Green.
    Under such circumstances, I would condone and approve of police brutality.  Only regretting I couldn't get in a few licks myself.  Though it would be difficult ^to decide whether Hell's Angels or Giant fans were more detestable.
    We  have a new drug available here and it is far more pernicious than CSD or even aspirin.  It is called CSphD and addicts are called alka heads.  It is an alkaline derivitave [sic] of Alka Seltzer.  It induces a state of total reality, far more dangerous than any hallucination.
    The effects are called "Staying Where You Are" or "Turning off"  During a "Stay" one friend of mine foreswore drinking, television and bowling.  Next day at the ad agency, he contributed something to the discussion of a name for a new
Completed

deodorant.  He now is looking for another, $30,000 per year job.

   I recently went to see about a job as an editor with a local text book publisher.  After having me fill out an eight page employment application, the employment lady (who also runs the switchboard) administered three tests.  One for spelling, one for their brand of grammar and one for my ability to spot mistakes.
   On all three I turned in three of the grandest ? they've ever seen.  And the employment lady was able to score all three in a mite over four minutes.
   After more than a year, I finally got around to calling Eric Solowitz.  A very perceptive fellow.  When I said "Orr" was the principal character in "Catch 22", he snorted and gave reasons I hadn't even thought of.
   With his help, I may yet write something worth reading.
   Remember God's word 

George
NEW ADDRESS - 2140 Hyde St.

in ink in top margin  circa 5 -65
Dear Jack

   Thought you'd like to know what's really going on in the South.
   Probably you read about that Negro con man getting 107 dollars from the Mayor of Selma.  This will set civil rights back a hundred years now that the segregationists have proof of Negros being smarter than Southerners.
   Please Jack, don't worry about those Beatniks over on the Berkeley campus.  Things have been tightened up to the point of banning the sale of Tums for the tummy.
   This came after someone noticed that Tums is smut spelled backwards.
   That's the sort of people they have in Berkeley.  Backward people.
   Well.  Cest la ball bounces.

George
P.S.  My poet friend Eric Barker was up from the Sur and we painted the town red.  Then we gave it a second coat.

   Now I'm going to be investigated for red activities.  Hope they don't find out about my Indian friends.  Not only do I know them but I sympathise with these reds.
Completed

Dec. 14, 1966
Dear Jack

   Sorry to hear about your reason for being in Moberly.
   I know how you feel.  Despite a fairly good record in the field I'm too old to get a trade magazine job.  Too old for most any sort of job.
   Just about anything I say will be trite.  You know the world belongs those who revel in the crappy old homilies.
   Or should we say, crappy homilies whether old or new.  Whether perpetrated by a Bircher or a Commie, by a learned prof or a benighted heathen, no think remains just that.
   I think of Ambrose Bearse.  Did he go south hoping to escape no think?  Hoping to find reason among the revolutionaries?  Perhaps to be killed for not agreeing with their brand of no think.
   Whatever, he'd have liked my Christmas story.   About the guy who so hated his boss that he got drunk our of sight at the office party.
   Next morning his wife told him, "You really did it with the boss last night."
   "Aaah, piss on him."
  "That's what you did last night and he fired you."
  "Fired me huh.  Fuck him."
  "That's what I did last night and you got your job back."

in pencil in top margin  [1969]
Dear Jack

    First let's stop all the buzz buzz around your office.  Here's what the little dog was doing on the skate board.
    Then, about a lecture date in the Bay Area.  It occurs to me that Rexroth might be helpful if/and we can think of some way that this might redound to his glorification.  I shall pursue this.
   Whatever else, remember that El Rancho 2030 offers you the Three Bs - Bed, Board & Booze.  So whatever else, your trip out here needn't cost you more than transportation.
   No, we aint got no Albee out here.  We have very little little theater besides having very little theater of any sort.  The performing arts in Frisco tend more to things like bare breasted broads doing the Frug.
   The Swim is passe  At the 'in' parties you'll see us doing the Drown.  Couples lie on the floor practicing mouth to mouth resuscitation.
   My good wife commends your solicitude and sends felicitations.  She continues biweekly therapy for the shoulder injured in a cable car last Armistice Day.  The gripman hit the slot brake and she hit the fron [sic] of the car.
   She sells a painting  now and again but at prices which help the ego more than the exchequer.  Or should I say privy purse since I never know what happens to the money.  
   We have learned to get along with damm [sic] little cash.  After deductions, our taxable income for 1964 was 2716.91.  The big nut is rent of which we pay none which is a damm good exchange for what little work we do as managers of the building.   Besides this all our utilities are paid and Alice gets a small salary plus a janitorial allowance.  Since this doesn't quite cover our costs, the whole matter comes down to a cash outlay of bewteen [sic] two and five dollars monthly.
    Since we got the building filled and kept it that way, thus reversing the trend in San Francisco to more vacancies, the owner regards us with deep affection.  This is enhanced by the ways I have shown him for saving money here and in his other buildings.
    Grateful for neighborly little favors, the tenants blame the owner rather than me when things aren't done quite the way they should be.  Besides, most of the favors (which I would do under any circumstances) are often repaid with a bottle of something or other which is supplemented by bottles from the owner who also owns a wholesale liquor company.

handwritten in left margin  PS:  I'm always tempted to address  you at Substandard Education Society but know how hard it is to find another sinecure these days.
Completed

Then there is barter.  I've got so good at this they've started calling me the big barter and egg man from the East.
   Eg:  My friend Mario needs some carpentry work done in his corner groceria.  (we call it the cornercopia)  Having got bids he then had me do the work for merchandise of value equal to the low bid plus the cost of materials and minus any applicable sales tax (he pays this on merchandise received regardless of whether or not he gives it away or sells it at a loss).  My profit (he's charging me retail so why shouldn't I charge him retail ?) is more than eough [sic] to cover the 4% and leave me a bit of cash besides.
   Only fault I have with this deal is that Mario didn't give me Blue Chip Stamps
   But Jack, have you heard about Pvt Goldfarb, a rookie in the Israli [sic] Army ?  He wanted a weekend pass to go see his girl friend in Tel Aviv.  But no passes for six months.
   Unless, he captures an Arab tank or three Arab machine guns.  So Goldfarb goes and gets an Arab tank and off to Tel Aviv as a minor hero.
   Then back to camp.  Couple of weeks later, Goldfarb comes in with a second Arab tank.  Mirabli, a week pass and this considerable hero has dinner with the Mayor of Tel Aviv.
   Then back to camp.  Less than a month passes before Goldfarb strikes again.  For his third Arab tank, Private Goldfarb is accorded a month pass, a Regimental Parade and the Colonel personally presents this great hero with a case of Mogen David.
    In Tel Aviv he is feted on all sides including dinner at the home of Ben Gurion.  After a few drinks he is less awed by these big shots and falls into conversation with the great man  himself. who finally says, "Private Goldfarb, I know you heros don't like to talk about your exploits, but how did you capture those Arab tanks ?"
     "Nothing to it Mr President.   I'd crank up one of our own tanks and drive out into the desert.    Then when I spotted an Arab tank I'd lean out and holler,  "Hey, you want a week end pass ? " "
   Enough of such nonsense, see if you  can decipher the enclosed cookie fortunes which Alice and I picked up at the tea garden in Golden Gate Park.

Cest la ball bounces
George 
handwritten in left margin    PS:  Would you like to invest in Alice's new invention, misfortune cookies?
Completed

in ink in top margin  circa 5-31-'71
Dear Jack

    Lucked out and had my long weekend last week.  Drove to Sonoma Thursday eve and stayed overnight so we missed most of the big wind.  Gusts up to 101 mph at Point Reyes hard by Bolimas where we had thought of going.  On the Gate bridge the wind was a steady 65 mph.
    Yesterday winds seldom exceeded 30 knots.  Today is calm so Frisco will be loaded with touristi. [sic]  Highways will be clogged with cars going from no place in particular to no other place in general.
    Except for Frau Kraut's eternal television and the UAAL (Upper Ariela Atheletic [sic] League) which is what we call the kids playing in Ariela street, the Marina is quiet.
    Billy Cisby is pitching with his right while his left holds the Kazoo on which he plays Battle Hymn of the Republic.  Never gets past where the grapes of wrath are stored.
    My arthritis is giving me Hell so I am going the route of asperin [sic] and Steam Beer.  Asperin helps my arthritis and Steam Beer helps me.  It is the only brew indigenous to America and now is brewed only in Frisco.  Contains no carbonation but gets its sparkle from "Casening" a rebrewing process akin to the refermentation of champagne.
Completed

Alice is readying for lunch with her chum Lee as I suggested they have it at Chumley's.  Quick trips to N.Y. are a family joke ever since my sister said she could put us up in her West 80 st digs in case of an earthquake here in San Francisco.
   Am sending the story about New Idrea in case you get nostalgiac [sic] about Monkey Camp.  also, so I can insert the bit about the chaps whose new Mercury was called in because it contained traces of tuna fish.
   Nothing changes, the rock scene gets rockier and the trip scene more acidioulous.   Some of us still manage to cling to our sanity and our beer bottles.  When driven to the wall I reread Archie and Mehitable and make bum jokes.
   The McCloskey Matress [sic] Co is liquidating all their water beds.  Curtailed some third class (junk) mail the other day and carried only a partial post.  About the PO you underlined: have to make jokes.
    After many interruptions it now is 11:00, at the Presidio, 21 guns are being fired while aircraft fly overhead to honor the dead.  I'm sure they're grateful. 
    So ask not what you can do to your country but what your country can do to you.

Allons
George
Completed

Dear Jack

   Only because I am with bronchitis and in need of diversion do you get a letter with the cuttings.
   Local 15's dinner dance was a ball.  A real meat ball.
   The Platypus Party seems to be a outgrowth of my work in Isn'tism, the theory of aggresive [sic] neutrality expressed in terms of dialectical immaterialism.
   Today, for the first time in a long time, there is sunlight in San Francisco.  But still the wind.  For months, the wind has blown every day.  Maddening.
   Great furore, the "Crime Commission" has criticized our local flics and fur is flying.  Now headlines read "Alioto Sues Nixon."  About what I do not know but it is a bad day when thieves fall out.
  For my part, I'd rather sue the Pope.  he has more money.

Allons
George
Completed

in different ink in top margin  Geo Hart  Jan 1, 1975
Dear Jack

  Good to know you're still doing business on the old stand.  I had begun to wonder.
  Another old friend, Harry Martin, from whom I had not heard for a year or more called yesterday from New York.  He's a wheel with Sperry and so can make all the calls he wants.
  Now the PO has phones plugged so we can't even make local calls.  I know some that aren't plugged, but don't want to risk the possible trouble for the sake of a dime.
  My new job with the PO is quite good.  Systems Support which, at my present level, pays about 17,000 a year.  Not the best but better than most.
  My hours are 3:30 to Midnight which keeps me out of trouble.  My days off are Wednesday and Thursday which keeps me out of weekend mobs.
Completed

Right now, Alice and I are shaking the last remnants of the flu and readying for our annual trek to Mexico.  Baha to be precise and this year hope to see the whales mate at Scammons Lagoon.
   Baha still has the advantages of being uncrowded and cheap.  Like beach front rooms for 11 to 15 dollars a day, double.  Lovely dinners with drinks, wine and tip for about 10 dollars. Fresh lobsters for a dollar or so.
   We missed last year because my back popped out so what I'm quoting are 1972 prices.  But, if you know where to go, there are bargains to be had.
   This was six months ago.  the McBrides wrote from England to quote some of the horrendous prices they were paying.  At that time they had no income tax to pay.  Now aliens must pay taxes and prices have gone way up.
    Perhaps I should send them a care package.
Completed

I shudder to think what will happen to food prices if the cost of oil and coal continue going up.  Our "efficient" American farms use from 10 to 20 calories of fossil energy to put one calorie on the table.
   As more fertilizer is need [sic] for soil depleted by monoculture the felony is compounded.  Guess we learned nothing from the Okie dust bowl.
   Oh yes, as part of my new job, I must occasionally go to school.  Ours is located at the University of Oklahoma in Norman.
   What a treat!

Moritorio te Salutanis
George
PS - Alice sends regards to Gladys and you.

   I'm sorry about the delay.   We see no problems with the program or the contract.  I am returning the copy of the release that you sent us with this letter.

   Format of the show will be as follows  

(Readings from First American Century Series Edition 2-63)
1  New Letters introduction

Passages were picked for dramatic effect, dialog, and subject matter that relates well to songs in Foolkiller repotorie, sp? [sic].  Tim Head, Robin Kratchmer, and myself will do the reading.  Bob Suckiel will do the music.

   I don't know if you've heard by now but we have bought the building at 39th & Main.  It's a nice 2 story building in an Art Decco [sic] style & a full basement.  It was built in 1923-26 and has been used as a speakeasy/nightclub - a "habadashery" run by Harry Truman & Eddy Jacobson, a bank, and most recently a candy factory (sweatshop)  There is a dirty book store across Main Street from us and a gay massage parlor across 39th St. from us, but all in all the public percieves [sic] the neighborhood as more "respectable" than the one we're in now. Jan. 25, 1949.
Dear Jack Conroy,

    Of course I remember the Rebel Poet, and other things and transactions of the not-too-remote past (the early 30's) as if it were only yesterday.   And I don't think I have changed much, nor have my circumstances.  The more things change, the more they remain the same, as the French say.  I edited a mimeographed magazine, Chanticleer, and now it's Solo - The One Man Magazine of Poetry.  I have heard from Hagglund, through the New Athenaeum (Will Tullon, Branson, Mo.); Seguin I lost track of 10 years ago.   
   I am glad to hear that you are still writing and publishing.  As for me, I rely on the mimeograph (pamphlets have become too expensive) as I am fed-up on rejection-slips.   
   I am sending you a copy of my last pamphlet (1947) "Man and Nature", 46 pp., half by me, (Man) and half, the Nature part, by Oscar Dudermans my brother-in-law.  Of course I am sending Solo, and will be glad to receive
Completed

your list of people who might care to get it.

   I am always on the look-out for new names.  That part in the write-up about "Poet-Publisher sends free magazine to underlined: Notables" is a lot of bunk.  I have sent some copies to "Who's Who" people sometimes for lack of a mailing list.  "The best things in life are free" - more baloney.  I was talking ironically, but was taken seriously.  No doubt many  people were dissuaded from asking for Solo because of the "Who's Who" slant which made such a good headline.
    I am going to the library when I have a chance to look up your works, and the history of the little magazine.  The library has done me the honor, recently, of asking for a file of "Solo" for their reference-room.
   Thanks for writing.  I am glad to know that someone remembers Chanticleer.  I announced "Solo", in the last issue of Chanticleer, for 1935.  It appeared in 1946.  I eventually carry out my promises.

Sincerely,
Jack Hauser

Kenwood, California
July 7, 1932
Dear Comrade Conroy:

    Your letter slightly delayed getting to me.  Thanks for the sentiments-certainly print the poem or letter if you wish, altho I enclose another copy which, I hope, is an improvement.
     Kenwood is near San Francisco, not Los Angeles.  It is close to Glenn Ellen, former home of Jack London.  I look after a friend's place for my board and a chance to do a little writing, at least theoretically.
    The Los Angeles and San Francisco John Reed Clubs have joined together to put out a magazine.  We were very favorably impressed with the L.A. delegation, and anticipate success.
    When I wrote you, the John Reed Club in S.F. was in a bad way, practically extinct.  However, a group got together determinedly and today it is growing by leaps and bounds.  Had the club been functioning as it is now, I should have submitted the poem to it for criticism.
     We have a headquarters, and the other night, so great was the enthusiasm that is [sic] was necessary to reopen the meeting after it had been adjourned and did not finish the discussion till after one oclock.  Quite a few of our group has real talent.

Fraternally,  Jack Haynes

Dear Jack,
The most immediate result of my trip south was the writing of 2 plays -- one on the organization of the South by the CIO and the other an anti Jim Crow anti red-baiting theme.  I would greatly appreciate it if you would be able to read them before publication so that in print they would show the healthy effects of your criticism and suggestions.  If you're willing, I could either mail it out to you or invite you to spend an afty or evening with us.  (My wife is rapidly becoming a damn good cook and she would love to have you to practice on.

  I think you will be pleased to learn (if you have not yet been informed) that a repertory theatre is in the process of organization.  Two meetings have already been held, a program agreed upon and an outline of action prepared.  As soon as the statement of policy is mimeoed I'll send you a copy.  I am convinced we are going to create real working class drama and produce it for large audiences...If we succeed we
Completed

2
will spearhead a renaissance in the cultural life of our nation that will far surpass even the flourishing period in the thirties that you did so much to bring into existence.  Would you help spread the word around?  (Temporary chairman is Ray Flerlage; name is People's Theatre.)  We want all socially conscious people who have talent in acting, singing, dancing, stage design, lighting, directing, and play-writing.  (Next meeting is at my home Wed Feb 26 at 7 30 pm -- all interested are cordially invited.

   Hoping to hear from you (Drat it I have no phone) I remain

Dear Jack,

    When I got up this morning it occurred to me I probably acted like a complete jerk in the manner which I deserted you guys last nite.  I had so enjoyed it, and wanted you all to stick around even though I was so pooped I just hadda lie down.  But instead of the words coming out graciously and making you feel at home even though the host hadda retire, they probably sounded just the opposite.  I hope you wren't offended - or rather  I hope you'll forgive me.  As does Terry, I have the highest regard and respect for you as a person and literary figure - and as I thought it over, I seemed ridiculous to myself for having been so rude to a guy who double underline:  is the father of proletarian literature in our country.   Sol & Joe & Ensi knew I didn't mean to be offensive but it was the first time you had been to our house and a wrong first impression sometimes never gets the chance to be corrected.

BRIEF COMPENDIUM OF NATURAL LAW
underlined:  Murphy's Law of Random Perversity
1)   Left to themselves, things go from bad to worse.
2)  Anything that can go wrong, will go wrong.
3)  If there is a possibility of several things going wrong, the one that will go wrong is the one that will do the most damage.
4)  If you play with a thing long enough, you will surely break it.
5)  If everything appears to be going well, you have obviously overlooked something.
6)  Nature always sides with the hidden flaw.
arrow pointing to #5 above  underlined:  Maltenfort's Variation  If, after the problem has been explained to you, you think there is a solution, the problem as you understand it is not very well understood.
underlined:  Gumperson's Law

   The contradictory of a welcome probability will assert itself whenever such an eventuality is likely to be most frustrating.

underlined:  Green's Law
There is no substitute for dumb luck.
underlined:  Hecht's Variation
Clever planning will never completely replace ...
underlined:  Mahle's Law
Nothing is ever simple.

1429 Central Ave.
Deerfield, Ill.  60015
Nov. 21, 1976
Dear Jack -
Yes, we're still here in Deerfield...though Josh (who'll be 26 in Dec.) is now living near Portland, Oregon and Becky, who got married last Oct.  (and is teaching in the same Deerifled [sic] grammer [sic] school she attended as a youngster) has an apt. in Evanston, leaving only Naomi, who'll be 18 next month, at home.  . and chances are if we can manage the funds she'll be off to college someplace next year.  I can appreciate what the loss of your daughter must have meant to you, and especially the suffering she went thru, and therefore what you and Gladys went thru'...cause we lost our youngest to cancer in Feb. '73, a week after her 12th birthday, after a leg amputation at the hip.  You learn to live with that, but you never get over it, and the visions of her suffering still haunt.
After having two jobs shot out from under me in one year, I'm now working as a sales rep. for a manufacturer of corrugated box machinery, covering a territory from Winnipeg to Little Rock, Manitowoc to Western Nebraska...so yes, Missouri and Kansas are included.  If I can make it to Moberly on one of my jaunts I'll phone in advance to determine if a visit would be comfortable for you.  And thanks for the Foolkiller; I enjoyed your reminisce of Thomas Benton and Dellinger's piece on H.H. Lewis, who (would you believe!) had escaped me.
Did you know Vincent Ferrini?  A different kind of poet than Bergman, he hammered  at you with images out of his experiences as a factory worker--vivid, unusual, imaginative with a boldness that sometimes took your breath away--during his proletarian days.  A different kind of tenderness than what I find in Bergman, who is the most poignant poet I can remember.  Hard tenderness.  Does that sound like a contradiction?   Then how about a love poem (WINE OF THE HEART) that ends: 

   "We shall be together so long
    It will seem like yesterday
    For the blood of the tenement stopped
   And ours were the hands removing the blade."

Or this one to his son, weeping at a photograph of an Italian lad, blinded and handless from the War, learning to read Braille with his tongue:  (DISCOVERY) concluding like this:

    "be not bewildered
     by midnight 
     O child
     weeping among
    the weeds
    look
    hear
    the dance of his flute

    his stump is around
    your shoulders"

Anyhow, Ferrini has a base in Gloucester, where he lives, and the Univ. of Connecticut in Storrs has just published, in paperback, his selected poems with a magnificent introduction by George Butterick, his editor and friend.  Ferrini and I have been friends for almost 30 years, and in a note, he asks me:  "Can you give me some addresses for reviewing, magazines and newspapers?  I'll send him poop on the Chicago papers and ask Studs if a review can be gotten into underlined:  Chicago Guide maybe by Studs).
Is there a chance you could get a review assignment?  Whether or no, his book will

Nov. 21, 1976
T-- note in red ink:  Publisher of a daily newspaper in the Midwest.
You may not have heard of Jack Conroy.  He is one of the great figures of American literature.  Author, editor, book reviewer, story teller, anthologist.  THE DISINHERITED, a classic of a novel.  MIDLAND HUMOR, an anthology.  And on and on.
Jack's now 77, in exile in Moberly Missouri.  There was a time when he got books to review from the Chicago SUN TIMES and DAILY NEWS, but for reasons I don't understand--cause his mind is alert, his wit sharp, his judgement excellent, and he's a fine book reviewer--they don't ask him anymore.
If you don't have, and would like to build a good weekly book review page for your paper, I think Conroy could do a heluva job for you.  What he couldn't or wouldn't want to review personally, he could get fine reviewers for, cause he knows so many crossed out:  people writers.  I don't know what the economics of this are, and maybe this is a foolish dream, but a successful something like this could give your paper a distinction that would make it nationally known, give you fun, a sense of achievement, and give Jack a chance to earn a few bucks doing what comes naturally to him.
I am taking the liberty of enclosing a recent exchange of correspondence with Jack...and if you think my idea has some merit, write to Jack (or call him ) and sound him out.
OK?
Mike
PS?  Did I have the wit to have sent to you?

Newspaper article
FEELING SORRY LONG AGO
By Irwin M. Siegel, M.D.
It was early November, it was late afternoon, and it was raining.  I was completing the sixth month of my internship, assigned to the Cook County Hospital emergency room;  I enjoyed it.  However, the rain had cut visibility and business both to zero.  The hospital guards were even permitting some of the local indigents to escape from the cold and wet of the streets into the somber warmth of the dingy waiting room where some lay stretched out on hard wooden benches, covering themselves with newspapers for blankets.

   My change of shift was 20 minutes off.  I was thumbing a text on the emergency treatment of acute poisoning while intermittently staring through a dirty window at the dirtier street outside, pelted with waves of seemingly endless rain.  Just as I was about to fix my third cup of coffee, he appeared at the door.
   He was black, middle-aged, drenched to the skin and shivering.  Also he was blind.  You have to understand I have this thing about blindness.  A friend of mine studying to be a psychiatrist once told me it was an upward displacement of an unresolved castration complex.  Well, maybe.  Anyhow, my feelings about the blind have always been gut-strong.  His was a familiar story.  He was on welfare, living alone in a basement apartment.  Borderline nutrition and the dampness of his flat led from a simple cold to a persistent cough with chills and fever.  He couldn't afford public transportation.  He walked to the hospital for help.  By the time he arrived, he was so wet you couldn't tell the color of his clothes.
   Fortunately, my examination revealed nothing beyond a severe upper respiratory infection.  Certainly no pneumonia; early bronchitis at worst.  I dressed  him in hospital garb, putting his wet clothes to dry on the radiator, gave him a cup of hot coffee, and wrote two prescriptions, one for an antibiotic, the other for cough syrup.  I really wanted to hospitalize him, but he wasn't that sick, and I would have been severely criticized for unnecessarily utilizing a bed.  The pharmacy was due to close shortly and I didn't want him to get lost getting there, so I decided to walk over with him.
   The pharmacy was closed when we arrived, the service window shut, and the over-varnished door locked.   I rang the emergency bell.  No answer.  I rang again.  Still no answer.  I rang once more, this time insistently.  The door opened and I was confronted by an elderly man.
   He was shorter than I, and what little hair he had was gray and disheveled.  He badly needed a shave.  He wore a short dirty hospital coat with the sleeves rolled up.  It was wrinkled and stained and missing one or two buttons.  In is right hand he held a piece of fried chicken, a bite of which he was still chewing.
   "Well," he snapped, "what do you want?"
   "I have a patient here with a bad respiratory infection.  He needs two prescriptions filled."
   "The pharmacy is closed," he replied.  "He can get them filled elsewhere or come back in the morning."  He started to close the door.
   "But he hasn't got the money to pay for them privately, and besides he's blind, and it's difficult for him to travel."
   "I told you we're closed.  I've worked all day and now I'm finished."
   At this, he turned and walked toward the back of the pharmacy.  I followed him through the door between shelves of bottles and jars into a room heavy with pungent medical odors.  "Look, I'm sorry to be late."  I was begging by now.  "And I'm also sorry I interrupted your dinner, but this poor man could really use the medicine today.  It would be a mitzva if you could take a few minutes to fill the prescriptions."  I hardly expected the vigor of his response.
   "Mitzva!" he exploded.  "You speak to me of good deeds!  What do you call working in this crummy place day after day, having to spill out the rest of my life serving endless lines of miserable people, if not a good deed?  Isn't that enough?  Can't I even have my peace at the end of the day?  You can feel sorry if you want.  I stopped feeling sorry long ago.  I tried it and it doesn't change a thing.  Do you think I was always employed in a place like this?  Before the Depression, I used to have a store of my own.  A fancy place in a good neighborhood...but the competition of the big chains was finally just too much.  I lost everything, and here I am, in the back of a crummy county hospital pharmacy, eating a chicken dinner out of a greasy paper bag.  So don't talk to me about good deeds."
    We found ourselves quietly looking at each other.  He had been gesticulating wildly in the air with the chicken, but his right arm now hung limp at his side.  After a few minutes of silence, I turned to leave.  I was almost to the door when I heard him mumble.
   "Oh, what the hell, give me the prescriptions."
   It didn't take long to prepare the medication.  I tried to thank him as he handed them to me.
   "Forget your thanks," he said.  "Just leave quickly, so I can finish and read my newspaper."
   It was still raining we walked back to the emergency room.  It was also dark outside, and the unshielded light fixtures in the high ceilings cast a naked glare on the cold, cracked walls of the hollow corridors.  I was caught somewhere between that bitter disillusioned man's loneliness and the ever renewing excitements of my young enthusiasm.  The blind man was also in there someplace.  In fact, as we walked silently along, with his arm gripping mine for guidance, I had difficulty telling where his hand ended and my arm began.  It suddenly seemed to me as though I would never be wholly rid of him, and I felt strangely as if I were my own father.

italics  Irwin M. Siegel, M.D., is now an orthopedic surgeon, practicing on Chicago's North Side.

That was a lovely letter you wrote, and a crossed out: girl young lady away at school should be getting mail from home now N then.  She needs to be reminded she's loved N missed, and there's something in the written word the spoken can't match.

Oct. 29, 1977

   It was 1968...the year after the 6-Day War.  The signs in Lod Airport read "20th Anniversary:  1948-1968".  It was mother's and my first trip to Israel.  You may remember we went with a group of 15 that included Rabbi Mrs. Singer, some Bnai Torah Temple couples [ Shermans - Sonderlings -Bachmans] a coupla young school teacers, and a Jesuit priest from Loyola University in Chicago.
   I was the first one out that morning we were going to Yad Vashem, and as I was standing alongside our chartered bus waiting for the driver, the guide and the rest of our group,
Completed

2.
a man about my age came out of the hotel, walked up to me, said he'd heard at breakfast our bus was going to Yad Vashem, asked if there would be room for him and his wife.  The bus held 40 comfortably, there were 15 of us.  I invited him to get his wife and join us. (you understand I had no authority to make these decisions, but when did that ever inhibit me?  He introduced himself to me, a Mr. (I don't remember his first name) Light, from Montreal.  He thanked me, he and got his wife, joined us.  As I recall him, he was   5'-8", 5-9", a little shorter than me, built a little like me, stocky, open-face, bald patch toward the back
Completed

3
of his head, hair kinda strung out sideways from his ears, like Eliahu's, blondish as I remember it.

   We went.  No matter what you know about the Holocaust, or what you think you know, when you go thru' Yas Vashem, you realize you don't know a pintele.  Nothing prepares you for the chamber of horrors you go thru'.
   There are certain kinds of pain I endure best alone.  I don't want to see any body, talk to any body, touch any body, share with any body.  It comes from having grown up an only child to ? parents, lonely in the firmative [sic] years.  One learns to make it alone.
Completed

4

  I'm not sure if it was by crossed out:  acciden happenstance or design that once inside I got separated from the group ..I suspect by design .. and so I staggered thru' the chamber of horrors alone.   Nothing in my life moved me, angered me, enraged me, chewed on me as that did.  What right did I have to be alive, when so many thousands, millions many I'm sure, better, kinder, more talented, more intelligent, more deserving than I, gone?  By what grace of Providence, by what accident of birth and geography am I walking and they buried?  How little I  knew, how little I gave, to help, to avert the slaughter .. and how that realization tore at me!
Completed

5.

  Solemn I went in and dazed I came out.  The bright, almost overpowering -- or so  it seemed by contrast -- sunlight was more than my eyes or I could handle.  Then, like in a fog, I noticed  25 maybe 30 feet ahead was a door to another building and I went inside.
   It was an exhibit of paintings by inmates of the concentration camps, some of them children, all painted in the camps.  Most of the painters never made it out of the camps.
   Two paintings side-by-side caught my attention most forcefully.  They were very simple paintings. - A street.  An overpass over the street.  Some buildings on the left.  A barn.  A horse and wagon.  No top or sides to the wagon.  Milk cans being loaded on it.  The two paintings were almost
Completed

6.
identical, with but one difference.  The painting on the right had people.  The painting on the left - no people.

   And then it struck me with full vigor.  With the two paintings, the artist was showing you first the town when the Nazis first came in, then the town after they had finished their "business."  In its simplicity, like a sledgehammer.
    As I stood there, the comprehension sinking in, I heard a sobbing behind me.  I turned around.  It was Mr. Light.  "That was my village, in Poland," he said ... and I could begin to feel goose pimples. . . "I was 9 years old when they came.  That's the main street.   They wrote a law:  Jews were not permitted to walk on that street.  To do so was punishable by death.  The overpass
Completed

7.
was to enable us to cross over."  And he went on to identify every detail, and to confirm how precisely the artist had captured and rendered it all.

    And then began my exhileration.  In the midst of all the carnage, human beings had created!  Knowing they would not come out alive, they created!  Not knowing if their creations would survive, they created!  Nothing, nothing, nothing literally nothing, could squelch the creative urge, so powerful it is.  A sensitive Nazi, an understanding Nazi -- if those are not contradictory, impossible words -- to see even one of these paintings in the camps he would have realized he couldn't win.  No matter what the power, his side could not win.
Completed

8

  Do you understand what I'm saying?  You can kill people, you can slaughter them wholesale, you can deprive them of any hope of life, and there will be them among them who will still create.
    I don't know if this is the divine speck manifesting itself as part of an eternal display of defiance --  "Wrong forever on the throne, right forever on the gallows, yet that gallows sways the future" - - or if it is a conscious or subconscious or even unconscious reaction of that handful -- that saving remant [sic] history calls them .. in whom hope of the future, in whom the vision of a better, a more rational tomorrow, cannot be obliterated even when they know there is
Completed

9.
no hope for them as individuals.  "I will die but humanity will live."

   And my exhileration grew.  Oh, those Israelis!  Do they know how to give a needle to the world.  Right next to the Memorial for the Dead is a l'Chayim To Life -- an Art Museum.  Paintings by the victims.  The thumb to the nose, the other 4 fingers waving.     And there is Mr. Light ... and by now I'm marvelling at the symbolism of his name ...  numbers on his arm, who knows by what miracle he survived, now a husband, a father, maybe a grand father, who by his very presence, by his aliveness, says:  "The Final Solution" wasn't final.  They got 6 million of us, but we're still bearing witness, with our Yad
Completed

10.
Vashem, and with our art exhibit along side, and with our  survivors parenting children.

    Naomi, I am not among those who believe it can't happen again.  I think it can.  And if it does happen again, it will be the American Jews to whom it will happen, and conceivably in your lifetime.  And to you.   I have no easy answers.  Sometimes I don't even know how to ask the right questions.
    About the only thing I can crossed out:  tell  suggest to you is you crossed out:  damn well better should never forget who you are.  You are a Jew, the child of Jews, who in turn are the children of Jews...and should you want to forget, the world won't let you.  The remembrance of that may not save your life...but it will your people.

Nothing in my life moved me, angered me, enraged me, chewed on me as that did.  What right did I have to be alive, when so many thousands, millions many I'm sure, better, kinder, more talented, more intelligent, more deserving than I, gone?  By what grace of Providence, by what accident of birth and geography am I walking and they buried?   Solemn I went in and dazed I came out.  The bright, almost overpowering -- or so  it seemed by contrast -- sunlight was more than my eyes or I could handle.  Then, like in a fog, I noticed  25 maybe 30 feet ahead was a door to another building and I went inside.
   It was an exhibit of paintings by inmates of the concentration camps, some of them children, all painted in the camps.  Most of the painters never made it out of the camps.
   Two paintings side-by-side caught my attention most forcefully.  They were very simple paintings. - A street.  An overpass over the street.  Some buildings on the left.  A barn.  A horse and wagon.  No top or sides to the wagon.  Milk cans being loaded on it.  The two paintings were almost

identical, with but one difference.  The painting on the right had people.  The painting on the left - no people.

   And then it struck me with full vigor.  With the two paintings, the artist was showing you first the town when the Nazis first came in, then the town after they had finished their "business."  In its simplicity, like a sledgehammer.
    As I stood there, the comprehension sinking in, I heard a sobbing behind me.  I turned around.  It was Mr. Light.  "That was my village, in Poland," he said ... and I could begin to feel goose pimples. . . "I was 9 years old when they came.  That's the main street.   They wrote a law:  Jews were not permitted to walk on that street.  To do so was punishable by death.  The overpass

was to enable us to cross over."  And he went on to identify every detail, and to confirm how precisely the artist had captured and rendered it all.

    And then began my exhileration.  In the midst of all the carnage, human beings had created!  Knowing they would not come out alive, they created!  Not knowing if their creations would survive, they created!  Nothing, nothing, nothing literally nothing, could squelch the creative urge, so powerful it is.  A sensitive Nazi, an understanding Nazi -- if those are not contradictory, impossible words -- to see even one of these paintings in the camps he would have realized he couldn't win.  No matter what the power, his side could not win.

  Do you understand what I'm saying?  You can kill people, you can slaughter them wholesale, you can deprive them of any hope of life, and there will be them among them who will still create.
    I don't know if this is the divine speck manifesting itself as part of an eternal display of defiance --  "Wrong forever on the throne, right forever on the gallows, yet that gallows sways the future" - - or if it is a conscious or subconscious or even unconscious reaction of that handful -- that saving remant [sic] history calls them .. in whom hope of the future, in whom the vision of a better, a more rational tomorrow, cannot be obliterated even when they know there is

   And my exhileration grew.  Oh, those Israelis!  Do they know how to give a needle to the world.  Right next to the Memorial for the Dead is a l'Chayim To Life -- an Art Museum.  Paintings by the victims.  The thumb to the nose, the other 4 fingers waving.     And there is Mr. Light ... and by now I'm marvelling at the symbolism of his name ...  numbers on his arm, who knows by what miracle he survived, now a husband, a father, maybe a grand father, who by his very presence, by his aliveness, says:  "The Final Solution" wasn't final.  They got 6 million of us, but we're still bearing witness, with our Yad

And if it does happen again, it will be the American Jews to whom it will happen, and conceivably in your lifetime.  And to you.   I have no easy answers.  Sometimes I don't even know how to ask the right questions.
